newsitem.title: YUGOSLAVIA: London Club team in Belgrade next month - official.
newsitem.headline: London Club team in Belgrade next month - official.

text.p: Yugoslavia expects a delegation of commercial bank creditors to visit Belgrade for debt talks in September, a senior government official said on Thursday.
"We will have a meeting with our London Club creditors here in the first half of next month," said Vuk Ognjanovic, chief Yugoslav negotiator.
"The two delegations will discuss certain elements relevant for the resumption of official talks to be held in mid-October," he said.

In July, Yugoslavia ended a second round of talks with its bank creditors in an attempt to settle the country's $2 billion share of commercial debt left over from former Yugoslavia after its violent break-up five years ago.
Analysts say settling Belgrade's debt is complicated by two law suits and lingering hostility in the aftermath of the Yugoslav conflict.

Belgrade has sued Slovenia and its creditors in London's High Court. Slovenia arranged a debt agreement which excludes paying back any Yugoslav holders of debt, who are reported to have been active buyers of ex-Yugoslav debt on the secondary market.
Ognjanovic said Yugoslavia would pursue its legal battle against Slovenia's rescheduling agreement with London Club creditors.
"Yugoslavia did not and will not withdraw the law suit against the Slovenian deal," he said. "We are just protecting our own interests."
Belgrade alleges the deal contravenes the 1988 New Financing Agreement (NFA) that shared out equal responsibility for assets and liabilities between former Yugoslav republics.

Yugoslavia has also prepared a law suit against Croatia, which negotiated a similar agreement with bank creditors. But Belgrade has yet to file the suit and apparently hopes the threat of legal action will give it leverage in debt negotiations.
"The law suit is prepared and is on the table as we want a constructive development of the talks with our creditors," he said. "And it can be filed any time."
But Belgrade analysts warned the suits could damage Yugoslavia's position by angering the international financial community, which it needs to help finance the country's economic recovery.

Dividing up the assets of the former Yugoslav federation is seen as a key condition for completing individual republic's efforts to settle their share of outstanding debt estimated at about $4.3 billion.
Slovenia has agreed to shoulder 18 percent of the total debt of ex-Yugoslavia, while Croatia took on 29.5 percent.
Macedonia and Bosnia are still in the process of negotiating similar accords. Macedonia is expected to take on five percent and Bosnia about nine percent of the debt.
Belgrade only began negotiating with bank creditors earlier this year due to U.N. sanctions imposed on Yugoslavia for its role in the Bosnian war. The sanctions were suspended last November.
